message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An extra-articular calcaneal fracture requires imaging of the spine to rule out any associated injuries before proceeding with further management options such as a long leg cast or open reduction and internal fixation. MRI of the right ankle may provide more detailed information about the injury, but spine imaging is necessary first in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an extra-articular calcaneal fracture, which usually does not require immediate surgery. The most appropriate next step is to rule out spinal injuries, as falling from a height can cause spinal injuries. X-ray of the spine can help rule out any spinal fractures. Once spinal injury is ruled out, further management of the ankle fracture can be decided.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a calcaneal fracture, which does not require immediate surgical intervention. An MRI or open reduction and internal fixation are not necessary at this point. The most appropriate next step would be to obtain an X-ray of the spine to rule out any spinal injuries caused by the fall.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an extra-articular calcaneal fracture, and the most appropriate next step is to rule out any spinal injury with an x-ray of the spine. MRI and open reduction and internal fixation are not necessary at this point, and a long leg cast is not appropriate for this type of injury.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an extra-articular calcaneal fracture, and the priority is to rule out any spinal injury. X-ray of the spine should be done before any further management of the ankle fracture. MRI or surgery may be indicated depending on the severity of the ankle fracture, but these should not be done without first ruling out a spinal injury. A long leg cast is not appropriate for an ankle fracture.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an extra-articular calcaneal fracture and the next step in management should be an X-ray of the spine to rule out any spinal fractures, especially since the patient fell from a height of 10 feet. MRI of the ankle, long leg cast, and open reduction and internal fixation may be considered later for the ankle fracture, but the spine should be evaluated first.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. An extra-articular calcaneal fracture is not likely to require open reduction and internal fixation or a long leg cast, and an MRI is not necessary for diagnosis. However, the patient fell from a height of 10 feet, so a spinal injury cannot be ruled out. Therefore, the most appropriate next step in management would be an x-ray of the spine to rule out any spinal injuries.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with a calcaneal fracture. An X-ray of the spine is needed to rule out any spinal injuries from the fall before further treatment on the fractured ankle can be done. Options B and C are not appropriate for an extra-articular calcaneal fracture. MRI is not necessary at this time.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has an extra-articular calcaneal fracture, which can be managed conservatively with a cast. However, given the mechanism of injury (fall from a height) and the presence of abrasions on both lower extremities, it would be wise to rule out any concomitant injuries, such as a spinal fracture, with a spine x-ray. Option A is not necessary at this point and may not provide additional information about the ankle fracture. Option C is typically reserved for more complex fractures or if conservative management fails.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has a calcaneal fracture, which is not an emergency that requires immediate surgery. X-ray of the spine should be done to rule out spinal injury, which could be a life-threatening emergency. Once spinal injury is ruled out, the appropriate treatment can be decided. Therefore, option (D) is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient.
